content: The release of resources, e.g., the power ball, is overly strategic and frustrating. Coders know when and when not to release resources on the game board based on number of remains moves. When you make you last move the board floods with resources; which is their way of saying "buy something." They need to make generation random. Level trickery: a hard or super hard may not be quite that hard but "regular" levels at times are ridiculously hard. Balance bottom line with fun you'll make more $$.

content: Deceptive Advertising! After seeing several ads depicting a driving game, showing a truck trying to navigate a mountain road with rickety wooden bridges and other vehicles I thought I would give it a try. As it turns out, it is yet ANOTHER jewel matching game, identical to at least a half-dozen others. It even has the exact same bombs, propeller and other "power ups". I've played 40 levels, built two trucks to completion and the only driving done has been to move a truck a short distance.

content: While the game initially offers an enjoyable experience, its progression mechanics raise significant concerns. As players advance, the difficulty curve escalates to a point where success becomes highly improbable without considerable time investment or in-app purchases that provide gameplay advantages. This design strongly suggests a primary focus on monetization, potentially at the expense of sustained player engagemet. I highly recommend avoiding this game.

Then you spend 15 pts to take off tires & rims, 15 pts to put on rims, 15 pts to customize rims, 15 pts to customize center rim plate, 15 pts to paint rims, 20 pts for tires, 15 pts to paint tires. 12 games won for just tires! Then there's another 10 parts per vehicle? I played and deleted after a day. Too much play for not enough reward. Do better.

content: it's incredible how many different ways this game actually cheats. Sometimes the game will just pretend you didn't match 5, and delete the tiles. Other times, it will delete random tiles during tile falls so that the tiles align differently than they actually would've if it wasn't cheating... once you get to a high enough level, you will see it easily with the naked eye. You can use screen recorder to prove it. The game cheats just to ensure you have to buy, or lose your streak. Crooked as hell.

content: While TS has potential, the difficulty spikes feel artificially inflated to push players towards in-app purchases. The incentive structure doesn't reward wins adequately, making progression slow without spending. This contrasts with games like Monopoly Go, which offer more consistent enjoyment regardless of spending. The relentless upsells create a feeling of being pressured to pay, diminishing the overall fun. I'd prefer a more balanced approach where skill and time investment are rewarded.

You need to watch players and how they play, not ask them if they want "more conversation" or not. You start the survey with an NPS question. Terrible.
